reviewText: If you are a fan cheesy 1950's & 1960's sci-fi flicks, you have got to see "Trail of the Screaming Forehead", a belly-laugh homage/parody of the genre.The basic story is that two sailors taking a break from transporting some frozen cadavers upriver stop off in the sleepy little town of Longhead Bay. Unfortunately, they've chosen the exact moment of an alien invasion for their few days of relaxation.  Oh, and I guess I should mention the invading aliens look like human foreheads. At the same time a scientist is conducting forehead experiments on her love-smitten assistant. The scientist believes all knowledge actually resides in the forehead instead of the brain.The movie is so goofy, but so well written that you will find yourself chuckling throughout. There were quite a few laugh out loud moments, and the acting is pitch perfect. Everyone plays it straight and serious, which makes the lunacy on-screen that much more funny. Toss in a few cameos by well known B-movie horror icons like Kevin McCarthy, Dick Miller and James Karen and you know you're in for a good time.Definately unusual, but extremely entertaining.
summary: Laugh Out Loud Parody of Classic Horror Films

reviewText: Being a Larry Blamire fan, needless to say I was pumped to get this film. I was not disappointed, it turned out to be the same cornball style comedy that I expect from Larry and the crew. While not as good as the Lost Skeleton of Cadavra series, it still stands on it's own two feet.
summary: Your forehead will perspire... from laughter!

reviewText: When it comes to creating movie parodies, Hollywood seems at a complete loss of how to do it right.  Cashing in on a quick trend and ANYTHING popular at the moment, studio representations (Date Movie, Epic Movie, Superhero Movie--need I go on?) are really just a collection of sight gags and gross-out humor that are loosely tied together with no respect for characters or story.  It's slapdash, lazy moviemaking by committee.  It has been a long time since the genius of "Airplane."  When I saw that fringe filmmaker Larry Blamire had created a movie called "Trail of the Screaming Forehead," I really didn't expect much.  Of course, the title is irresistible but I assumed the resultant product would (at best) be a bit of silly fun.  And yes, it is silly fun.  But it is so much more as well.  Blamire understands that a great spoof requires a respect and love for the original source that is being poked fun of.  Parody and homage go hand and hand--and "Screaming Forehead" is a loving and hilarious tribute to the bad sci-fi epics of the fifties.Two sailors on shore leave enter a quaint coastal village.  Among the oblivious innocents and ingenues they encounter, a deeper mystery lurks.  Mad scientists are at work and the townsfolk are slowly but surely being taken over by what appears to be an alien race.  Yes, unexplained foreheads are slinking around town and once they attach themselves to someone, the host is overtaken and becomes a part of a new nefarious army.  With the help of a plucky town librarian, the trio find themselves in deep waters as everyone around them seems to be joining the forehead collective.  Blamire incorporates his stock company (you've seen most everyone in his cult classic The Lost Skeleton of Cadavra) as well as some terrific cameos by some genre icons.  My favorite--Kevin McCarthy from the original "Invasion of the Body Snatchers."  Everyone is fully committed to their roles, though, but stand-outs have to be the town villain and his sexy chanteuse.I know how ridiculous everything sounds, and it is.  But here's the rub--this screenplay is surprisingly smart and sophisticated.  Just listening to the dialogue is an absolute treat to fans of clever wordplay.  The movie is downright hysterical because it never panders down to its audience.  For a cheesy bit of fun, this is one of the most literate and intricate screenplays that I've encountered in some time.  Add a terrific cast, excellent period details, laughably appealing special effects, a musical number or two and "Trail of the Screaming Forehead" becomes the most unexpectedly delightful film.  Truly, I loved it and that caught me by complete surprise.  If Blamire created this film in 2007, how has it not been released on the DVD market in over four years?  It's an absolute crime.  A genuinely funny parody that even the smartest of movie lovers can enjoy.  An easy recommendation!  KGHarris, 9/11.
summary: A Loving Homage And A Blisteringly Funny Spoof--After Four Years And Still No DVD Release?  Really?

reviewText: Larry Blamire has made a career out of making extremely silly parodies of late '50s/early '60s low-budget science fiction movies.  His first such movie, The Lost Skeleton of Cadavra, is a classic, and if anyone reading this hasn't seen that movie, please do yourself a favor and do so (and its sequel, The Lost Skeleton Returns Again).  Trail of the Screaming Forehead was his follow-up effort, and even though this is an extremely funny movie, distribution problems have prevented a region 1 DVD from being released even to this date, so in a sense this is the "lost Larry Blamire movie".  It's a darn shame, too, because all of the things that make his movies so funny are abundantly on display here.  This movie is an homage to the "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" genre, where aliens come to earth and take over the bodies of unsuspecting humans.  The catch is that the aliens are forehead creatures; they "used to be like us" but then there was a nuclear war and they were somehow reduced to just their foreheads.  This isn't as bad as it sounds, because the movie makes a compelling case that the forehead, not the brain, is the seat of all human intelligence, and by injecting a forehead compound called Foreheadazine into the skull, one can become super-smart.  This is every bit as ridiculous as it sounds, and the cast hams it up with great glee.  All of Blamire's usual crew are here, plus some newcomers, and everyone does a great job.  I have to particularly single out Andrew Parks as the clueless scientist, and Brian Howe as an "old salt" kind of sailor.  Also, Larry Blamire's eccentric wordplay is all over this movie, and I have to fight to keep from typing in quotes because I don't want to spoil them for you.  Unlike Cadavra, this movie is not in black-and-white but in gloriously ultra-ultra-saturated color, reminiscent of when low-budget movies first started being produced in color and had to emphasize the color as much as possible, even when there was no reason to do so (check out the ridiculously colored chemicals in the lab, for instance).  The special effects are also completely over-the-top, particularly the forehead prosthetics.  And the ending is... beyond ridiculous.  Basically, if you like Lost Skeleton of Cadavra, you can't go wrong with this film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: No effort of any kind is made to take the plot seriously.  The actors are flawless, which makes it work.  If you have a silly sense of humor, this is the film for you.  I have not found it in the American format but I can play it on my computer.  It is rarely on TV and you will be so glad you got it in your collections.I suppose a plot summary might help.  A doctor is convinced that intelligence comes from the forehead and not from the brain.  When she poses this theory that laugh at her and tell her "I want you to leave.  Before that, I want you to resign and then I want you to get out of here"  She must prove her theory in 24 hours.  She is aided by another doctor who finds himself with free time. His project was going nowhere.  He tried to find the connection between the lips and the brain but apprently there is none.  The things just move by themselves.Meanwhile aliens in the shape of foreheads are on the attack!
summary: Wonderfully awful!  The best bad movie you will ever see

reviewText: I now own all of the Larry Blamire DVDs. All of the movies are loving homages/parodies of B- and C-grade movies from the 50s, 60s, and 70s. I love them all.
summary: Truly, so painfully bad that it is delightful

reviewText: First as another reviewer said this doesn't play in my DVD player which is no big whup.  I played it in the computer which was fine by me but that is not the disappointment.  This film compared to his others SUX.  Back when, I rented "The Lost Skeleton of Cadavera" and liked it so much I bought it and the sequel "The Lost Skeleton Returns" both excellent.  Then I got "Dark and Stormy Night" and watched it 3 times in a row.  It is fantastic. If you want to get a Larry Blamire film I suggest one or all of those 3, not this lame-o Forehead thing.  The Lost Skeltons and Dark and Stormy have great commentary tracks too which Forehead lacks.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, you'll need a Region 2 friendly DVD player to watch this.  It was never released in America/Region 1 and after watching this movie it is easy to see why.I'm a big fan of Larry Blamire's films but this movie feels unfinished compared to all of the others.  Various set pieces are pretty humorous but the movie never really gels into a cohesive whole.  Lots of bits are repeated, the worst offender being the eponymous theme song.However its not all bad.  Larry Blamire knows his B-movies and the parody is as sharp and spot on as ever.  All the repertory players you know and love from the Lost Skeleton films make an appearance and do not disappoint.Viewers with Region Free DVD players who have seenThe Lost Skeleton of Cadavra (Special Edition),The Lost Skeleton Returns Again, orDark And Stormy Nightand crave more of the same absurdist retro hijinks you've come to love and expect from Larry Blamire and company should go ahead and pick this one up, but newbies should start with any of the classics listed above.
Title: N/A
